div.p: An order catalog exposes a homogeneous collection of healthcare items that can be ordered or selected by practitioners during the course of care delivery. These homogeneous healthcare items may represent services, products, devices or knowledge artifacts. Each item specifies its purpose, describes how it should be ordered and/or used, and characterizes the outcomes that one can expect from this usage.

Examples include order sets catalog, evidence based CDS content, laboratory test compendium, medication formulary, catalog of medical devices. Order catalogs have varied scopes, sizes, ownerships and targetted consumers and jurisdictions. For instance an order catalog might expose the medical devices of a particular manufacturer to the potential users of these devices in a country. Another catalog might consolidate all the medical devices that are approved for use in healthcare throughout the Europe Union market. Another example of order catalog would be a drug formulary listing the medicinal products that are available for prescription in a particular hospital. A broader catalog of medicinal product might include all the medications authorized to the national market of a country.

A catalog provides reference data, which aggregates requirements of usage for the items of the catalog, from multiple sources: regulatory, clinical knowledge, organizational (based on the organization of the provider of the items).

Catalogs are meant to be used by IT systems and applications (e.g. EHR, EMR, CPOE, apps, LIS, Pharmacy system ...) as well as by humans. Humans interact with catalogs through the mediation of their applications.
Client applications may interact with a catalog to:

ul.li: browse through entries of the catalog and retrieve items of interest together with the detailed instructions and guidance related to the usage of these items,
import/export the full catalog or a part of it (e.g. import the recent updates),
administer the content of the catalog: add/update/retire items and/or supporting resources.
